Welcome to invadr! This app accompanies the website http://ias-ess.org - the unified Invasive Alien Species (IAS) sighting and monitoring website.

invadr allows you to contribute to this important cause. If you think you spot an invasive (check out the gallery!) - snap it and send it. You\'ll be asked to fill out a very short questionnaire (typically up to 5 questions) and your sighting will be added to the website after verification by an expert.

Invasive Alien Species (IAS) exert a persistent, pervasive threat to UK biodiversity and also incur significant socioeconomic costs to the UK economy (Child & Wade 2000, Dehnen-Schmutz, 2004, Williams et al. 2010). At the UK scale, the annual the annual economic cost of IAS has been estimated to be approximately £165 million yr-1; globally, this figure is in the region of US$120 billion yr-1 (Pimentel 2005).

As the ecological and socioeconomic impacts of IAS are becoming increasingly apparent, at a range of spatial and ecological scales; efforts are being made to avoid invasions or to manage and control established invaders (Joshi et al. 2004). Timely, high-quality population and spatial data for these invasive taxa is essential for: 1) ecological analyses; 2) informing stakeholders and 3) informing “best practice” management and control efforts (Joshi et al. 2004, Ustin et al. 2002).

References

Child, L. & Wade, M. (2000), The Japanese Knotweed Manual: The Management and Control of an Invasive Weed. (pp. 4 - 20). DPS Partnership Ltd., Burgess Hill, West Sussex.
